pullRequest.title: [#901] Added support for annotated handler interceptors
pullRequest.bodyText:
This commit adds support for interceptors declared on the handler
instance itself, using the same rules for parameter injection as other
annotated handlers. Depending on the annotation used, handlers are also
given the opportunity to only act on the result of handler execution,
such as a specific type of exception.
Resolves #901

commit.message:
Added support for annotated handler interceptors

This commit adds support for interceptors declared on the handler
instance itself, using the same rules for parameter injection as other
annotated handlers. Depending on the annotation used, handlers are also
given the opportunity to only act on the result of handler execution,
such as a specific type of exception.

Resolves #901

Validate whether the current interceptor, the delegate, can handle the message and if true do so.
If false, we proceed over the chain by calling next.handle

Is that a correct assumption from my part?
I think this piece of code is slightly clearer if you rename handlersPerType to interceptorsPerType.
I am not completely sure why this if block can be removed with these changes. Would you mind explaining this part?

I believe the sorted call has been removed since the interceptors have already been sorted by the HandlerComparator.
I am just not 100% of the filter removal. Was this filter call a duplicate to begin with?
The part after the || is only intended to keep supporting the deprecated InterceptorChainParameterResolverFactory#initialize method, right?

And if so, isn't this assurance already taken care of by the MessageHandlerInterceptorDefinition.InterceptedMessageHandlingMember itself, were we validate if the InterceptorChain has been given as a parameter (hence called) and if not we call proceed ourselves?
Why not test the @ExceptionHandler scenario here too?
Just to clarify, the unwrapping is now necessary because you've introduced the ClasspathHandlerDefinition on the test subject, correct?

I don't "feel" what this call is verifying, as I don't notice any assertions.
Is it just the fact it traverses through the class hierarchy, ending up in the interceptor?

Why not also assert whether the value from the MetaData is populated in e.getMessage()?
Pretty sure it works though, just wondering.
This tests look identical with testWrapExceptionInResultInterceptor.
Why not test the @ExceptionHandler cases here too?
Just to make sure I am on the right path. The unwrapping is necessary because you switched from the AnnotatedMessageHandlingMemberDefinition to the ClasspathHandlerDefinition, right?
I am uncertain what this chain call actually tests at the moment.

I cant seem to be able to wrap my head around this one line here.
Is this done so that we do not enforce users to inject the InterceptorChain in an @ExceptionHandler annotated method (which feels fair tbh)?
And subsequently, that it doesn't matter in which part of the InterceptorChain the ResultHandlingInterceptorMember resides?
Isn't this super.canHandle check already performed in the local canHandle call? What's the scenario when this is false so that the exception needs to be thrown again?
What if the user didn't call InterceptorChain#proceed, even though a parameter was added to the @MessageHandlerInterceptor annotated method?
So, the canHandle method will/can actually call handle too? Or, will the parameter already be resolved if we perform canHandle?
